title: Garlic mouthwash shows shockingly strong germ-fighting power
summary: Garlic extract is emerging as a surprisingly powerful contender to chlorhexidine, the long-standing "gold standard" in antimicrobial mouthwashes.

title: Humans are built for nature not modern life
summary: Human biology evolved for a world of movement, nature, and short bursts of stress—not the constant pressure of modern life.

title: The rotten egg smell that could finally beat nail fungus
summary: Researchers have identified hydrogen sulfide as a surprisingly effective tool for treating difficult nail infections.

title: New fat-burning diabetes pill protects muscle and appetite
summary: Researchers have developed a new oral drug that boosts metabolic activity in muscle rather than altering appetite like GLP-1 drugs.

title: Scientists say this viral rosemary skincare trend actually works
summary: Researchers have found scientific support for the viral claim that rosemary can improve wound healing.

title: Scientists keep a human alive with a genetically engineered pig liver
summary: Researchers successfully implanted a genetically modified pig liver into a human, proving that such an organ can function for an extended period.

title: Scientists find hidden layers in brain’s memory center
summary: Scientists uncovered a surprising four-layer structure hidden inside the hippocampal CA1 region, one of the brain’s major centers for memory, navigation, and emotion.

title: Natural hormone unlocks a hidden fat burning switch
summary: FGF19 triggers the brain to burn more energy and activate fat-burning cells, offering a potential new path for obesity treatments.

title: Next gen cancer drug shows surprising anti aging power
summary: A next-generation drug tested in yeast was found to extend lifespan and slow aging by influencing a major growth-control pathway.

title: A CDC panel has struck down universal newborn hepatitis B vaccination
summary: A reshaped vaccine committee voted to scale back newborn hepatitis B shots despite decades of data showing the birth dose is safe, effective and vital.

title: Big Neandertal noses weren’t made for cold
How male seahorses tap into their mothering side
Scientists find hidden brain nutrient drop that may fuel anxiety
summary: Researchers found that people with anxiety disorders consistently show lower choline levels in key brain regions that regulate thinking and emotions.

title: Scientists reveal a powerful heart boost hidden in everyday foods
summary: Regular consumption of polyphenol-rich foods like tea, coffee, berries, nuts, and whole grains may significantly support long-term heart health.

title: Experimental RNA treatment shows surprising DNA repair power
summary: Cedars-Sinai scientists have created a new experimental drug called TY1 that helps the body repair damaged DNA and restore injured tissue.

title: Alzheimer’s blood tests may be misleading for people with kidney problems
summary: A large study found that people with impaired kidneys tend to have higher Alzheimer’s biomarkers, yet they don’t face a higher overall risk of dementia.

title: How a bacterial toxin linked to colon cancer messes with DNA
_Nanotyrannus_ is still not a teenage _T. rex_
A volcanic eruption might have helped bring the Black Plague to Europe
Simple nutrient mix delivers surprising autism breakthrough in mice
summary: A low-dose mix of zinc, serine, and branched-chain amino acids boosted neural function and social behavior in autism mouse models.

title: Daily coffee may slow biological aging in mental illness
summary: Researchers studying people with major psychiatric disorders found that drinking up to four cups of coffee a day is associated with longer telomeres.

title: Scientists capture flu viruses surfing into human cells in real time
summary: Scientists have captured a never-before-seen, high-resolution look at influenza’s stealthy invasion of human cells, revealing that the cells aren’t just helpless victims.

title: Gas stoves are filling millions of homes with hidden toxic air
summary: Stanford researchers found that gas stoves expose Americans to surprisingly high levels of nitrogen dioxide—often matching or exceeding outdoor pollution.

title: Human-caused earthquakes are real. Here’s why even stable regions can snap
Ancient DNA reveals China’s first ‘pet’ cat wasn’t the house cat
A 70-year-old pregnancy drug just revealed a hidden weakness in brain cancer
summary: Researchers have solved the decades-old mystery behind how a common pregnancy drug lowers blood pressure, and it turns out the medication blocks a fast-acting “oxygen alarm” inside cells.

title: Is your gut being poisoned? Scientists reveal the hidden impact of everyday chemicals
summary: Researchers discovered that 168 common chemicals can disrupt the growth of beneficial gut bacteria, with some also promoting antibiotic resistance.

title: A routine shingles shot may offer powerful defense against dementia
summary: A unique vaccine rollout in Wales gave researchers an accidental natural experiment that revealed a striking reduction in dementia among seniors who received the shingles vaccine.

title: Scientists reveal what really drives the “freshman 15”
summary: College life creates a perfect storm for overeating, as students consume more calories when surrounded by friends, eating in dining halls, or following unstructured schedules.

title: A common constipation drug shows a surprising ability to protect kidneys
summary: Researchers found that lubiprostone can protect kidney function, and the results point toward gut-based, mitochondria-boosting therapies as a promising new avenue for CKD care.

title: Your sweat reveals health problems long before symptoms appear
summary: Sweat carries a rich mix of biomarkers that advanced wearables can now track in real time, and new AI-powered patches analyze biochemical patterns to detect disease risks.

title: Scientists boost lifespan by 70% in elderly male mice using simple drug combo
summary: Scientists found that combining oxytocin with an Alk5 inhibitor revitalized extremely old male mice, boosting their lifespan and strength.

title: A long-overlooked weak point in your DNA has just been revealed
summary: Scientists discovered that the first 100 base pairs of human genes are unusually prone to mutations, especially during the earliest stages of embryonic development.

title: Twisted stacks of 2-D carbon act like a weird type of superconductor
Self-hypnosis with cooling mental imagery could ease hot flashes
Fast depression relief? Nitrous oxide shows remarkable potential
summary: Nitrous oxide may offer quick, short-term relief for people with major depression, especially those who haven’t responded to standard medications.

title: Scientists discover first gene proven to directly cause mental illness
summary: Scientists have discovered that a single gene, GRIN2A, can directly cause mental illness—something previously thought to stem only from many genes acting together.

title: Doctors are seeing more aggressive breast cancer in younger women than expected
summary: Younger women are being diagnosed with breast cancer more often than screening guidelines anticipate, and many of these cancers are invasive and harder to treat.

title: Personalized ‘prehabilitation’ helps the body brace for major surgery
summary: A small study finds that individualized prehab can dampen harmful immune responses and may reduce complications after an operation.

title: A therapeutic HPV vaccine shrank cervical tumors in mice
summary: An HPV vaccine delivered into the nose can treat cervical tumors in mice. The vaccine targets a cancer protein produced by the virus.

title: New brain imaging breakthrough reveals clues to Parkinson’s
summary: A high-speed “zap-and-freeze” method is giving scientists their clearest view yet of how brain cells send messages, and the insights could help explain why most Parkinson’s cases emerge without inherited genetic changes.

title: Scientists reveal five big moments when your brain dramatically changes
summary: A large study of brain scans shows that our neural wiring evolves through five major stages from birth to late old age, and these phases are separated by sudden turning points that mark big shifts in how the brain is organized.

title: Fructose may quietly supercharge your inflammation
summary: Researchers found that fructose can prime immune cells to overreact to bacterial toxins. In healthy adults, fructose-sweetened drinks increased receptors that trigger inflammation. This heightened sensitivity may contribute to greater infection risk. The effects could be even more dangerous in people with metabolic diseases.

title: How Statins Can Cause Muscle Damage
summary: Statins have been transformative for many individuals, by lowering cholesterol, and reducing the risk of heart problems ...

title: Most Dogs Still Carry Some Wolf DNA
summary: Many dog owners may not be surprised to learn that most dogs still carry some wolf DNA in their genomes. Domestication h ...

title: Your skin has a built-in cancer defense and sunlight turns it off
summary: Scientists have uncovered how too much sunlight can flip a hidden switch inside skin cells that makes inflammation spiral out of control and increases the risk of cancer. Their research reveals that UV radiation breaks down a protective protein called YTHDF2, which normally prevents a small RNA signal from activating an immune sensor linked to dangerous inflammation. Once that protection is lost, a surprising chain reaction unfolds inside the cell, turning ordinary sun damage into a potential cancer trigger.

title: Scientists discover a hidden brain circuit that rewrites vision
summary: MIT scientists found that what we see is strongly influenced by how alert or active we are.

title: Why some memories last a lifetime while others fade fast
summary: Scientists have uncovered a stepwise system that guides how the brain sorts and stabilizes lasting memories.

title: Scientists find a hidden obesity trigger in soybean oil
summary: Researchers at UC Riverside have uncovered why soybean oil, one of America’s most widely consumed ingredients, drives significant weight gain—at least in mice. The findings point not to the oil itself but to the fat-derived molecules it produces inside the body, called oxylipins, which can trigger inflammation, alter liver function, and influence genes tied to metabolism.

title: RSV prevention in newborns could cut asthma risk
summary: Scientists found that RSV infection early in life can set the stage for childhood asthma, particularly in kids already genetically prone to allergies. The virus appears to skew the developing immune system toward exaggerated responses to everyday allergens. But when newborns were protected from RSV, asthma development was prevented. The results point to a powerful added benefit of RSV prevention tools now being rolled out globally.

title: Millions are about to choose the wrong Medicare plan
summary: Millions face Medicare decisions each year, but many don’t take advantage of tools that can save them money and stress. Insurance marketing often overshadows unbiased options like SHIP, leaving people unaware of better choices. Comparing real costs—not just premiums—can prevent unpleasant surprises, especially when provider networks or drug rules change. New assistance programs for low-income adults offer valuable help for 2026.

title: Hidden blood molecules show surprising anti-aging power
summary: Scientists have identified new anti-aging compounds produced by a little-studied blood bacterium. These indole metabolites were able to reduce inflammation, oxidative stress, and collagen-damaging activity in skin cell cultures. Three of the compounds, including two never seen before, showed particularly strong effects. The findings hint at a surprising new source for future skin-rejuvenation therapies.

title: Where cannabis stores cluster, emergency visits climb
summary: Researchers analyzed data from over six million people to see how close residents lived to cannabis retailers. Neighborhoods near these shops experienced higher cannabis-related emergency visits compared with those farther away. The effect was strongest where multiple stores were packed into small areas. These trends suggest that store density plays a meaningful role in community health.

title: Repeated head impacts may quietly break the brain’s cleanup system
summary: Researchers found that repeated head impacts can disrupt a key system that helps the brain wash away waste. In professional fighters, this system initially seems to work harder after trauma, then declines over time. MRI scans revealed that these changes may show up years before symptoms do. The work could help identify at-risk athletes earlier in their careers.

title: Canada just lost its measles elimination status. Is the U.S. next?
summary: Canada has had more than a year of continuous measles transmission. The United States has until January to limit cases before losing status.

title: The 'Miracle Mineral Solution'—amazing cure or toxic illusion?
summary: Miracle Mineral Solution, also known as MMS, has been marketed for years as a purported miracle cure for various conditions, including cancer, autism, and COVID-19.

title: Patients are more than participants: What meaningful engagement really looks like—and why it improves health research
summary: When we talk about "patient engagement" in research, it can sound like a slogan on a grant application rather than something that changes people's lives.

title: Scientists find toxic metals hidden in popular plastic toys
summary: A large-scale Brazilian study found dangerous levels of toxic metals in popular children’s toys, with barium and lead topping the list. Researchers used sophisticated lab methods to identify 21 hazardous elements and test how easily they could be released when toys are mouthed. Even though only small fractions leach out, the total concentrations were so high that safety concerns remain critical.

title: A popular “essential” medicine may be putting unborn babies at risk
summary: A major review across 73 countries finds that access to antiseizure medications is rising, but safe prescribing isn’t keeping pace. Valproate—linked to serious birth defects—remains widely used in many regions despite WHO warnings. Limited access to newer drugs means millions may still be at risk. Researchers urge global education and stronger safeguards.

title: Bird flu’s surprising heat tolerance has scientists worried
summary: Researchers discovered why bird flu can survive temperatures that stop human flu in its tracks. A key gene, PB1, gives avian viruses the ability to replicate even at fever-level heat. Mice experiments confirmed that fever cripples human-origin flu but not avian strains, especially those with avian-like PB1. These findings highlight how gene swapping could fuel future pandemics.

title: Hidden mitochondrial DNA damage may be a missing link in disease
summary: Researchers identified a new, sticky form of mitochondrial DNA damage that builds up at dramatically higher levels than in nuclear DNA. These lesions disrupt energy production and activate stress-response pathways.

title: Scientists uncover the brain’s hidden learning blocks
summary: Princeton researchers found that the brain excels at learning because it reuses modular “cognitive blocks” across many tasks. Monkeys switching between visual categorization challenges revealed that the prefrontal cortex assembles these blocks like Legos to create new behaviors. This flexibility explains why humans learn quickly while AI models often forget old skills. The insights may help build better AI and new clinical treatments for impaired cognitive adaptability.

title: Scientists studied 47,000 dogs on CBD and found a surprising behavior shift
summary: Data from over 47,000 dogs reveal that CBD is most often used in older pets with chronic health issues. Long-term CBD use was linked to reduced aggression, though other anxious behaviors didn’t improve. The trend was strongest among dogs whose owners lived in cannabis-friendly states.

title: Polluted air quietly erases the benefits of exercise
summary: Long-term inhalation of toxic air appears to dull the protective power of regular workouts, according to a massive global study spanning more than a decade and over a million adults. While exercise still helps people live longer, its benefits shrink dramatically in regions with heavy fine particle pollution—especially above key PM2.5 thresholds common in many parts of the world. The researchers emphasize that outdoor activity shouldn’t stop, but better air quality could unlock far greater health gains.

title: Smoking Hemp on a Processed Diet Increases Cardiac Risk
summary: Smoking cannabis while eating a highly processed diet weakens the immune system and increases risk of cardiac problems.

title: Mutation Hotspots in the Human Genome are Discovered
summary: Scientists have revealed parts of the genome that are especially vulnerable to mutations that occur very early on in dev ...

title: Microplastics May Contribute to Heart Disease
summary: Exposure to microplastics may directly contribute to clogged arteries.

title: Hidden Immune Cells Drive Type 1 Diabetes
summary: Nearly two million Americans are affected by type 1 diabetes. Diabetes occurs when the body cannot produce enough insuli ...

title: New Cannabis Compound Shows Potent Skin Benefits
summary: How can cannabis compounds be used to improve skin health? This is what a recent study published in the Journal of Natur ...

title: Nasal Drops Improve Brain Cancer Treatment
summary: Glioblastoma is a rare, aggressive, brain tumor that is difficult to treat. It originates from brain cells known as glia ...

title: 1 in 5 Young Adults Use Cannabis to Fall Asleep
summary: Over 20% of young adults report using cannabis or alcohol to help fall asleep.

title: Bird flu viruses are resistant to fever, making them a major threat to humans
summary: Bird flu viruses are a particular threat to humans because they can replicate at temperatures higher than a typical fever, one of the body's ways of stopping viruses in their tracks, according to new research led by the universities ...

title: When ribosomes collide, cells launch emergency stress defenses
summary: Ribosomes, the protein factories of the cell, are essential for all living organisms.

title: A common nutrient deficiency may be silently harming young brains
summary: Scientists studying young adults with obesity discovered early indicators of brain stress that resemble patterns seen in cognitive impairment. The group showed higher inflammation, signs of liver strain and elevated neurofilament light chain, a marker of neuron injury. Low choline levels appeared closely tied to these changes.

title: Your body may already have a molecule that helps fight Alzheimer’s
summary: Spermine, a small but powerful molecule in the body, helps neutralize harmful protein accumulations linked to Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s. It encourages these misfolded proteins to gather into manageable clumps that cells can more efficiently dispose of through autophagy.

title: Stunning new 3D images reveal yellow fever’s hidden structure
summary: University of Queensland researchers visualized yellow fever virus particles at near-atomic detail, uncovering major structural differences between vaccine and virulent strains.

title: A Mitochondrial DNA Mutation that Alters Immunity
summary: Mitochondria are well known as the powerhouses of the cell because of their energy generating capabilities. These little ...

title: Drug Resistance Genes Easily Move Among Organisms & the Environment
summary: Bacterial cells can easily swap bits of DNA, and many of those pieces of genetic material carry genes that confer resist ...

title: How statins harm muscles—and how to stop it
summary: Statins have transformed heart health, saving millions of lives by lowering cholesterol and reducing the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

title: Strategies to keep drug discovery research alive in the US despite funding cuts
summary: In the face of US federal funding cuts, biomedical researchers propose strategies for continued progress in drug discovery.

title: New study shows rheumatoid arthritis begins long before symptoms
summary: Rheumatoid arthritis begins years before pain ever appears, and scientists have now mapped the hidden immune battle that unfolds long before symptoms.

title: A hidden brain energy signal drives depression and anxiety
summary: Scientists discovered that lowered brain energy signaling in the hippocampus can lead to both depression- and anxiety-like behaviors in mice. Stress reduced ATP, a molecule important for cell energy and communication.

title: Exploring the Outcomes of Genome Editing in Non-Dividing Cells
summary: The CRISPR gene editing technique has had a dramatic influence on biomedical research, and has even been applied to a fe ...

title: Eight Trajectories of Long COVID are Identified
summary: Since the emergency phase of the COVID pandemic has ended, researchers have been studying the long-term consequences of ...

title: Scientists Call Age-25 Cannabis Rules a Myth
summary: What should be the minimum legal age for recreational cannabis? This is what a recent study published in The American Jo ...

title: Intranasal Nanotherapy Shows Promise Against Glioblastomas
summary: A novel nasal-delivered nanotherapy has shown promise against glioblastomas in mice.

title: Low Dose Aspirin Helps Prevent Cardiovascular Events in T2D
summary: Adults with type 2 diabetes and a moderate or high risk of CVD were less likely to experience a serious cardiovascular e ...

title: Advancing patient-reported outcomes in cancer clinical trials
summary: The SISAQOL-IMI consortium, co-led by the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) and Boehringer Ingelheim (BI), has published a paper in The Lancet Oncology outlining how its recommendations for ...

title: Pill form of semaglutide fails to slow Alzheimer's in large trial
summary: A pill version of semaglutide, the ingredient in Ozempic and Wegovy, did not slow the progress of Alzheimer's disease, drugmaker Novo Nordisk announced on Nov. 24.

title: The body trait that helps keep your brain young
summary: Scientists discovered that more muscle and less hidden abdominal fat are linked to a younger biological brain age. Deep visceral fat appeared to accelerate brain aging, while muscle mass offered a protective effect.

title: ‘Butt breathing’ could help people who can’t get oxygen the regular way
summary: Takanori Takebe’s strange investigation into whether humans can use the gut for breathing has surprisingly sentimental origins: helping his dad.

title: 3,000 steps per day might slow Alzheimer’s disease
summary: In people at risk for Alzheimer’s disease, researchers linked minimal to moderate physical activity to a 3-to 7-year delay in cognitive symptoms.

title: Doctors still outperform AI in clinical reasoning, study shows
summary: AI may ace multiple-choice medical exams, but it still stumbles when faced with changing clinical information, according to research in the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Two parallel blood formation systems produce different immune and blood cells
summary: It has only recently become known that two parallel systems of blood formation exist in the body, originating from different precursor cells.

title: Microprotein adipogenin helps fat cells store lipid droplets
summary: Researchers have found that microprotein adipogenin plays a key role in helping fat cells store lipid droplets, which is important for metabolic health.

title: Immune cells use a surprising trick to heal muscle faster
summary: A research team has found that specific immune cells can connect with muscle fibers in a lightning-fast, neuron-like way to promote healing.

title: Your brain shows damage before your blood pressure even rises
summary: Hypertension begins harming the brain surprisingly early, even before measurable blood pressure increases. Key cells related to blood vessels, signaling, and myelin maintenance begin aging prematurely and malfunctioning.

title: One protein may hold the key to fixing leukemia treatment failure
summary: Scientists have uncovered how leukemia cells manage to escape one of the most commonly used treatments.

title: A tiny enzyme may hold the key to safer pain relief
summary: Researchers have uncovered a surprising way the brain switches pain on, revealing that neurons can release an enzyme outside the cell that activates pain signals without disrupting normal movement or sensation.

title: Boosting one protein helps the brain protect itself from Alzheimer’s
summary: Researchers discovered that raising the protein Sox9 can help the brain’s astrocytes clear out toxic plaque buildup linked to Alzheimer’s. In mouse models that already showed memory problems, activating these cells improved cognitive performance.

title: New nasal nanodrops wipe out brain tumors in mice
summary: A new nasal-delivered nanotherapy shows promise against aggressive glioblastoma tumors.

title: New evidence shows tirzepatide and semaglutide strongly protect the heart
summary: A massive real-world study comparing tirzepatide and semaglutide reveals both drugs deliver strong, early cardiovascular protection.

title: Scientists reveal a hidden hormone switch for learning
summary: Researchers uncovered how estrogen subtly reshapes learning by strengthening dopamine reward signals in the brain.

title: Building a better skin barrier
summary: Skin is a barrier meant to keep small invaders out. Products making their way across it should boost that mission.

title: Chemerin receptor structures disclose new mechanism of lipid metabolism
summary: Chemerin is a key adipokine that regulates lipid metabolism and insulin sensitivity, and thus is involved in many metabolic diseases such as obesity and diabetes.

title: Population-specific genetic risk scores advance precision medicine for Han Chinese populations
summary: Researchers have developed the first population-specific polygenic risk score models for people of Han Chinese ancestry, achieving unprecedented accuracy in predicting risks for common diseases.

title: Simple amino acid supplement greatly reduces Alzheimer’s damage
summary: Researchers discovered that the common amino acid arginine can block harmful Aβ aggregation and reduce its toxic effects in Alzheimer’s disease models.

title: A drug already in trials may stop chemotherapy nerve damage
summary: Researchers discovered that chemotherapy can accidentally trigger a stress alarm in immune cells, causing inflammation that damages nerves.

title: Immune Cell Activation Through a Novel Molecule Improves Cancer Therapy
summary: Immunotherapy has revolutionized the way physicians treat patients. Previously, chemotherapy was the standard-of-care wi ...

title: Bone Marrow Model Made from Human Cells
summary: Researchers recently developed a bone marrow model to study how the body generates cells. Interestingly, this model is t ...

title: Molecule Produced During Exercise Slows Aging
summary: The health benefits of exercise have potential to be reproduced in pill form.

title: Amino Acid Arginine Shows Promise for Treating Alzheimer's
summary: Amino acid arginine has shown promise in reducing the buildup of amyloid-beta plaques in animal models of Alzheimer's di ...

title: A diet low in glutamate may ease migraines
summary: People with Gulf War Illness found relief from migraines after a month on a low-glutamate diet, hinting at a new way to ease symptoms.

title: mRNA flu vaccines are making their way through clinical trials
summary: The mRNA platform offers the advantage of faster vaccine production, which could allow more time to decide on which flu strains to cover.

title: In animal tests, this needle-free insulin acted as fast as injections
summary: Managing diabetes with injections is challenging. Joining insulin to a skin-penetrating polymer was as effective as shots at regulating blood sugar.

title: The Role of a Cancer-Linked Protein in Wound Healing is Revealed
summary: High levels of a molecule known as serpinB3 are known to be a reliable marker of serious diseases including inflammatory ...

title: How Rabies Does So Much with So Little (Genetic Material)
summary: Like many viruses, the rabies virus has a relatively small genome compared to most organisms. Scientists have now reveal ...

title: Ozempic Improves Survival Among Colon Cancer Patients
summary: GLP-1 receptor agonists like Ozempic and Wegovy may increase survival among patients with colon cancer.

title: Common Gout Drug Reduces Cardiovascular Risk
summary: A widely available drug used for gout may help prevent heart attacks and stroke in people with cardiovascular disease.

title: The Loss of This Protein Alters Muscles' Reaction to Testosterone
summary: A gene known as ACTN3 has earned the nickname "the gene for speed" and it may have an influence on how androgens...

title: Some Viruses Can Significantly Raise Heart Disease Risk
summary: Scientists have recently conducted a meta-analysis of over 150 research studies, and determined that infections with vir ...

title: Prenatal Cannabis Disrupts Neurodevelopment into Adulthood
summary: Heavy cannabis use during pregnancy negatively affects fetal brain development and these effects persist into adulthood.

title: Patients with Dementia Show Positive Cognitive Improvements After Sustained Medical Cannabis Use
summary: A study published in the Journal of Alzheimer's Disease found that patients suffering from dementia demonstrated cog ...

title: Study Highlights the Safety and Efficacy of Inhaled Cannabis for Treating Refractory Diabetic Neuropathy
summary: A study published in Biomedicines found an association between cannabis use and sustained pain reduction in a patient po ...

title: A tiny ancient virus reveals secrets that could help fight superbugs
summary: Scientists mapped the Bas63 bacteriophage in unprecedented detail, uncovering how its tail machinery infects bacteria.

title: How Gut-Brain Signaling Reduces Post-lllness Appetite
summary: After an illness like the flu, symptoms may go away while a person still feels lousy. Researchers wanted to learn more a ...

title: Why Severe Long COVID is 3X More Likely in Women Than Men
summary: The COVID pandemic brought many challenges, one of which is the chronic problem known as long COVID that can develop aft ...

title: Gum Disease Linked to Brain White Matter Damage
summary: Older adults with gum disease have more signs of brain white matter damage than those with good periodontal health.

title: Microgravity Muscle Printing Paves Way for Space Biomanufacturing
summary: Can muscle tissue be 3D-printed in outer space to improve astronaut health? This is what a recent study published in Adv ...

title: Engineered Antibody Improves Treatment for Autoimmune Disorders
summary: Autoimmune disorders occur when the body’s immune system cannot differentiate between cells that are its own and p ...

title: Novel Nasal Vaccine Prevents Respiratory Disease
summary: Over the last few decades, the development of nasal vaccines has been used to deliver treatment for various diseases, in ...

title: Strange microscopic structures found in Long COVID blood
summary: Scientists have discovered strange microscopic structures in the blood of people with Long COVID—clusters of tiny microclots tangled together with sticky immune webs known as neutrophil extracellular traps, or NETs.

title: COVID-19 Vaccine Linked to Fewer Allergies and Infections
summary: A new study found that children who received the COVID-19 vaccine had lower rates of infections and allergies compared t ...

title: The Early Life Gut Microbiome is Linked to Emotional Health
summary: Scientists have now found that the composition of the gut microbiome during childhood can have an influence on whether a ...

title: The Mechanism Behind a Common Virus is Revealed
summary: Astroviruses may not be well known, but they are very common and are the leading cause of diarrhea in children...

title: This 14th century story fooled the world about the Black Death
summary: Historians have traced myths about the Black Death’s rapid journey across Asia to one 14th-century poem by Ibn al-Wardi.

title: A new blood pressure calculator built on extensive clinical trial data helps doctors accurately estimate how much each medication will reduce blood pressure.
summary: The tool simplifies complex treatment choices and replaces unreliable BP measurements with solid evidence.

title: AI unravels the hidden communication of gut microbes
summary: Scientists have turned to advanced AI to decode the intricate ecosystem of gut bacteria and their chemical signals.

title: Doctors found a way to stop a deadly metformin reaction
summary: A hospital in Thailand created a quick-action dialysis protocol for patients with metformin-associated lactic acidosis, a dangerous reaction to a common diabetes drug.

title: A simple DNA test could reveal the right antidepressant for you
summary: Scientists in Sweden, Denmark, and Germany are developing a genetic test to predict which medications will actually work.

title: DNA’s hidden power could transform how we make medicines
summary: Scientists found that DNA’s phosphate groups can direct chemical reactions to make the correct mirror-image form of drug molecules.

title: Stanford makes stem cell transplants safer without chemo
summary: A Stanford-led team has replaced toxic pre-transplant chemotherapy with a targeted antibody, allowing children with Fanconi anemia to receive stem cell transplants safely.

title: COVID vaccine linked to fewer infections and allergies in kids with eczema
summary: New research suggests the COVID-19 vaccine could help children with eczema stay healthier overall. Vaccinated kids had lower rates of infections and allergies, including asthma and rhinitis, compared with unvaccinated peers.

title: Rare desert berry could transform diabetes treatment
summary: An extract from a desert berry used in traditional Chinese medicine restored insulin function and stabilized metabolism in diabetic mice.

title: Wegovy in a pill? Massive weight loss results revealed
summary: Novo Nordisk’s oral semaglutide 25 mg achieved up to 16.6% weight loss in a landmark study, rivaling injectable Wegovy.

title: Nanotech makes cancer drug 20,000x stronger, without side effects
summary: A Northwestern team transformed a common chemotherapy drug into a powerful, targeted cancer therapy using spherical nucleic acids.

title: Scientists shocked to find E. coli spreads as fast as the swine flu
summary: Researchers have, for the first time, estimated how quickly E. coli bacteria can spread between people — and one strain moves as fast as swine flu.

title: A shapeshifting protein explains rabies’ deadly power
summary: Researchers discovered how rabies virus exerts massive control over host cells with very few genes. A key viral protein changes shape and binds RNA, allowing it to infiltrate different cellular systems.

title: This new drug candidate might finally outsmart tuberculosis
summary: A new compound called CMX410 may change the fight against tuberculosis. It targets a weak point in the bacteria’s defenses, even in drug-resistant forms of the disease.

title: Breakthrough brain discovery reveals a natural way to relieve pain
summary: Using powerful 7-Tesla brain imaging, researchers mapped how the brainstem manages pain differently across the body.

title: Think melatonin is safe? New research reveals a hidden heart risk
summary: Long-term melatonin use for sleep problems may come with unexpected heart dangers.

title: A 25-year Crohn’s disease mystery finally cracked by AI
summary: UC San Diego researchers combined artificial intelligence with molecular biology to unravel how immune cells in the gut decide between inflammation and healing.

title: Scientists reverse anxiety by rebalancing the brain
summary: Researchers have discovered a specific set of neurons in the amygdala that can trigger anxiety and social deficits when overactive. By restoring the excitability balance in this brain region, they successfully reversed these symptoms in mice.

title: MIT scientists discover how the brain spins back into focus
summary: Researchers at MIT’s Picower Institute found that rotating waves of brain activity help restore focus after distractions. In animal tests, these rotations predicted performance: full rotations meant full recovery, while incomplete ones led to errors.

title: Scientists find mind trick that unlocks lost memories
summary: Researchers found that embodying a digital, childlike version of one’s own face helps unlock vivid childhood memories. This illusion strengthens the connection between bodily self-perception and autobiographical recall.

title: A groundbreaking brain map could revolutionize Parkinson’s treatment
summary: Duke-NUS scientists unveiled BrainSTEM, a revolutionary single-cell map that captures the full cellular diversity of the developing human brain. The project’s focus on dopamine neurons provides crucial insight for Parkinson’s treatment.

title: Ancient viruses hidden inside bacteria could help defeat modern infections
summary: Penn State scientists uncovered an ancient bacterial defense where dormant viral DNA helps bacteria fight new viral threats.

title: Alzheimer’s might be powered by a broken sleep-wake cycle
summary: Disrupted sleep patterns in Alzheimer’s disease may be more than a symptom—they could be a driving force. Researchers at Washington University found that the brain’s circadian rhythms are thrown off in key cell types, changing when hundreds of genes turn on and off.

title: Alarming surge in memory problems among young adults
summary: Cognitive struggles are climbing across the U.S., especially among young and economically disadvantaged adults. Rates of self-reported cognitive disability nearly doubled in people under 40 between 2013 and 2023.

title: Resetting the body’s rhythm could protect the brain from Alzheimer’s
summary: Researchers discovered that altering the body’s natural rhythm can help protect the brain from Alzheimer’s damage. By turning off a circadian protein in mice, they raised NAD+ levels and reduced harmful tau buildup.

title: Cannabis survey reveals rising CBD use in pets
summary: A recent survey has found that the use of CBD in pets is on the rise, with many owners using it to treat anxiety and pain in their animals.

title: Evidence lacking for cannabis to treat conditions
summary: A review of the evidence has found that there is currently a lack of research to support the use of cannabis in treating a range of conditions, highlighting the need for further studies.

title: Muscle and belly fat linked to brain health
summary: Research has found a link between muscle mass, belly fat, and brain health, suggesting that maintaining a healthy weight and muscle mass may be important for cognitive function.

title: Monthly injection reduces steroids in severe asthma
summary: A new monthly injection has been found to reduce the need for steroids in patients with severe asthma, offering a new treatment option for those with the condition.

title: Nitrous oxide shows promise in treating depression
summary: Nitrous oxide has been found to have potential as a treatment for depression, with studies showing that it can rapidly improve mood in patients with the condition.

title: Analysis of association between cannabis consumption and oral cancer incidence
summary: A new analysis has examined the association between cannabis consumption and the incidence of oral cancer, with findings suggesting that there may be a link between the two.

title: Prompt TBI treatment reduces Alzheimer's risk
summary: Prompt treatment of traumatic brain injury (TBI) has been found to reduce the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease, highlighting the importance of early intervention.

title: RNA processing affects lifespan
summary: Research has found that RNA processing can affect an organism's lifespan, with implications for our understanding of aging and age-related diseases.

title: Iron deficiency impairs immune cells in lungs
summary: Iron deficiency can weaken the immune system by impairing the function of immune cells in the lungs.

title: Amino acid arginine shows promise in treating Alzheimer's
summary: The amino acid arginine has been found to have potential as a treatment for Alzheimer's disease, with research suggesting that it may be able to slow the progression of the condition.

title: Your ZIP Code could reveal your risk of dementia
summary: People living in socially and economically disadvantaged neighborhoods may face higher dementia risks, according to new research from Wake Forest University. Scientists found biological signs of Alzheimer’s and vascular brain disease in those from high-burden areas, particularly among Black participants.

title: Understanding Gut Neurons' Reaction to Allergens, Parasites
summary: There is such a specialized, complex network of neurons serving the gut that it is sometimes referred to as out second b ...

title: It sounds creepy, but these scientific breakthroughs could save lives
summary: From mini-brains to spider-inspired gloves and wolf apple coatings, scientists are turning eerie-sounding experiments into real innovations that could revolutionize health and sustainability.

title: Humans evolved faster than any other ape
summary: UCL scientists found that human skulls evolved much faster than those of other apes, reflecting the powerful forces driving our brain growth and facial flattening. By comparing 3D models of ape skulls, they showed that humans changed about twice as much as expected.

title: Scientists find hidden antibiotic 100x stronger against deadly superbugs
summary: A team of scientists discovered a hidden antibiotic 100 times stronger than existing drugs against deadly superbugs like MRSA.

title: Scientists Create Fungi That Destroys Mosquitoes
summary: Mosquitoes spread many deadly diseases, including malaria, and scientists have long been searching for ways to treat or ...
